posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

posts.com:
DC Shoes was started by Damon Way and Ken Block after the two met during a community college class and launched a series of startups. The two friends started Eightball clothing, Blunt Magazine, Type A Snowboards, and Droors clothing over the subsequent years. Droors Clothing then became DC Shoes in 1993.

After he sold DC Shoes to Quiksilver in 2004 for $88 million in cash and stock, many industry insiders wondered what Block, the brand's co-founder, would do next. He had an impressive track record already, with years of marketing and sales experience.

Next came HOONIGAN
Ken Block, Co-Founder AKA Head Hoonigan in Charge, Brian Scotto, Co-Founder

Ken Block was a cool dude badass driver and had cool cars. He never seemed to act like some stuck up rich cunt.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
RIP

People shit on him for his racing record but he started racing when most professional racers would be thinking about retirement. First time he sat in a racecar was for a DC Shoes corporate event, and he impressed the instructors so much they suggested he should get into racing. He would sell his share of DC shoes off to start the rally team a year later. He was genuinely talented driver, but was identified too late to be competitive. He was racing against drivers who had a minimum of 10 years of racing experience on him. The fact he could come out of nowhere and hold his own is proof of that.

The whole Hoonigan thing and his race record make it easy to clown on him, but once you start looking deeper you'll understand he was the real deal, who complete reorganised his entire life around motorsport once he discovered it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Thierry Neuville:
“Shocked and saddened to hear the passing of a true icon of our sport. A passionate racer and real pioneer that inspired so many of us. Rest in peace buddy. All my sympathies are with the family and friends.”

Hayden Paddon:
“Can’t believe the news today of Ken Block’s passing. Way too soon for someone who has done so much for our sport. It was an absolute pleasure working with you on some events and I can not imagine how hard this will be for family and friends. Passing on our best wishes to everyone! RIP but will never be forgotten!”

Dani Sordo:
"A tough day for motorsports and sports. My deepest condolences to the Block family and friends. Rest in peace Ken, and thank you for the great show you always gave us!"

Oliver Solberg:
"My hero, my friend. You were a true inspiration and I will be forever grateful for the opportunities and help you gave me. All my thoughts are with the family."

Petter Solberg:
"A top driver, a great friend, a family man, and an inspiration to millions all over the world. Today is a very sad day and all our thoughts are with Ken's amazing family."

Sébastien Ogier:
"Such sad news. Ken was a visionary, so passionate and inspiring. He knew like no other how to combine motorsport and a big show. He lived his life to the fullest and I'll never forget his smile and laugh. Sending my thoughts and support to his family and friends."

Gus Greensmith:
"The impact this man has left on the motorsport world will resonate for generations to come. A visionary & a pioneer of all things Hooning, there really was only one Ken Block. My deepest sympathies to the Block family."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Lots of salty edgelords in here.

Ken drove his first racecar at age 35.

At 35 many professional drivers retire.

He spent his early life building a fortune.
Not racing from age 12 like WRC drivers.
After selling his business, he lived the dream.

He knew he couldn't compete at the highest level at WRC.
He was too old, lacked 20 years of experience.
That was never the goal.
He did what he could do best to promote the sport, which was showmanship.
And it's really fucking good. Everything he did was really good.
You CANNOT argue that his Gymkhana videos are really good, unless you're a total sperglord.

Without Ken Block, Rally would be MUCH less popular.

Yes, the caps & graffiti & Monster stuff is kind of cringe for an older man.
But it worked to get people interested in cars, including myself back in 2010.

He drove the cars he wanted, had the fun he wanted.
He didn't compete to win world championships, but to win against his past self.
On top of this, he had a beautiful, intact family with multiple children.
How many people do you know who have even this?

This guy is an absolute inspiration
You cringelords can fuck right off back into your world of misery.
If it were up to autists like you, this would be another "purist" sport & WRC would fade into obscurity.

It's sad he never got to teach his sons how to drive.
At least he spent quality time with his daughter, building a car with her & having fun.
I'm sure he's waiting in heaven now to reunite with them and drive some sick donuts.

R.I.P. big man.
You will be missed.

posts.com:
Come join us this Saturday for the triple header special, a competition in 3 legs across 2 games testing speed and navigation skills.
First leg is an AC nordschleife snow race in the pikes peak cars, the fastest cars we have ever raced before. They are capable of around 6 minute lap times so sharpen up.
Then load the cars up in your trailer, take the wheel of your truck, and move from Cologne to Palermo in ETS2 with no navigation aids beyond a map and your skill at reading road signs.
Once at the Targa Florio, take the other car you prepared and try not to die around the long and treacherous vintage test.

Sign ups (put a link for your car for leg 3 if its not kunos stock content) and more infos on mods needed on the google doc
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1vlVjNh8r6o_KYUFHf7Hcp8ZaYS5lsEZwFvTeu_K_c1Q/edit#gid=1624127333

Note that the DLCs needed for the ETS2 part are currently on sale if you need em.

posts.com: Alright cunts. I posted a while ago about my shitbox F650 that wouldn't go above 60mph. I fucked about checking the valve clearances, which were all within tolerance and cleaned the carbs but the problem still persisted. I left it over Christmas because I was away visiting family and finally got back to it this morning. I slapped a new voltage regulator on it before but because i am a tremendous hemorrhoid I didn't bother checking the wiring harness. I split it open this morning and lo and behold there were a couple of wires coming from the reg had gone brittle and had the copper exposed. Replaced the wires and it is like a different bike. Full power again and a pleasure to ride. I still blame the jews for the previous crash and my lack of common sense in checking properly but am now very happy with my winter shitter. Cheers cunts

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26229845
If your low RPM output is marginal a large capacitor is cheap to try and those were used on many British bikes to replace or supplement the battery. This is how they mount. You can look up the capacitance online and they're so simple anyone can install one.

https://www.lowbrowcustoms.com/products/british-standard-capacitor-battery-eliminator-replaces-lucas-2mc-54170009

If you can find an auto electrical rebuilder who rewinds stators (or learn to do it yourself which is more tedious than difficult) a stock stator could be rewound for higher output. I mentioned that previously. Rewinders should be common in the third world because it saves so much money on car parts.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h_FTv-ZCZ4o

Example discussion but not for GN:

https://drriders.com/rewinding-stator-for-more-power-t19488.html

Wire and insulating varnish is cheap but the job must be done right and any leads to the ignition undamaged. A rewind plus a capacitor if successful (your ignition switch should ONLY power the ignition to start the bike) could mean no more batteries for life but batteryless systems are low output so LED headlight etc would probably be mandatory.

It's all been done elsewhere.

This bike was designed and manufactured in japan. It has a silver (the best colour) frame because it was forged in the fires of mount fuji, out of katana steel folded over 100,000 times, sourced from actual world war 2 era katanas. It has a V-four engine; the most bespoke of engine layouts, giving it the peak power of an inline four (commuter car layout), yet the power delivery of a vee twin (outdoor farm equipment engine). It produces 105 PS (claimed) (when new) (at the crank) (without accessories) (at sea level). Combining with this is the most aggressive weight reduction in VFR history: by swapping to a more traditional side exhaust, simplifying the braking system, and using a single radiator, a whopping 0kg was saved for a new wet weight of 240kg (over 0kg lighter than the 4th gen vfr750). The high power and low weight make for an effortless sport touring experience, allowing you to sports, touring, sports whilst touring, tour whilst sporting, and almost any motorcycle usage. VFR stands for Veee Four Racing, and while the “veeeee” sound of the gear cams no longer exists on this generation of engine, you can tell that it was still designed four racing. Lining up against a contemporary CBR1000RR - an almost more expensive motorcycle - the VFR800F was able to achieve a commanding second place in both the drag race and time attack. The veeeffarr’s prowess isn’t just its performance however, its also visually stunning with light emitting diodes for headlights, and finished in a beautiful starfire moonight pearl starlight metallic starmoon white; a white so white the owner must pay extra road tax. I will be out riding this amazing machine (in full leathers of course), if you see me, wave. The 180 degree V-IV is so smooth and stable - I’ll see you clearly in the reflection in my side mirror. Thanks for reading, and now: its VFR’n time.

>>26230254
I am definitely falling in love with wide American roads, huge V8s and lax photo enforcement. Can’t go 2 miles in metro Australia without seeing a speed camera, pig or red light camera. Cops sitting on the median can issue mail fines, they don’t even need to pull you over. So in that sense, the troopers here having to pull over only select idiots makes it seem much less efficient from a revenue raising perspective.

And they’ve got these towable mobile speed cameras, they tow them to spots on the highway, let it rip, then change it up every few days. Plus the fines are expensive. Up to 10kmh over (6mph) is ~$150 USD and 1 demerit (license has 12). More than 10kmh over is ~$250USD and 3 demerits. Doubled on public holidays and doubled for 2nd offences.

Mobile phone cameras ping you now for $1000 AUD (~$670 USD) and 5 demerit points

Haven’t had an issue with the traffic lights here yet but in Australia, there is almost never a turn left (equivalent to right turn in USA) on red, so you get stuck at intersections when any ol nigger (we have Indians and Asians in Aus) can safely turn 99.99% of the time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26230793
Cheap rubber. Other causes:
1.Direct sunlight slowly dry rots the rubber.
2.Rubber of the wipers gets full of dirt, this is what increases the wear of the wiper blades. Wiping them clean with wet rag or paper occasionally makes them last a little bit longer but if you rather be lazy and dont want to clean wiper blades then one alternative is to take the whole car into carwash. Dirty wiper blades is also one reason why wipers can get noisy during operation despite wiper blades being fairly new condition.

Silicone wiper blades cost more money, but also last longer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In a "bold" attempt at shitbox dress shoe design, the 1947 Davis Divan was an attempt at the three-wheeled car that ultimately ended in a similar vein as the Reliant Robin did in the UK, just a good thirty years prior to what is called the "Fiberglass Pig."

Its main selling point was its extremely good fuel economy for the day due to it being lightweight, and its ability to do tight donuts at a circumference of around 17 ft thanks to its single front wheel design. Its flaws, should be obvious even if they're to be considered "design choices."

Around fifty remain from the original production line as of today. The OP's picture is from 2021 in Amelia Island, Florida where three Divan curators took their pieces of garbage to an airstrip to drag race at a blistering 50mph for a hundred dollar grand prize. The airport was well aware of the stunt and endorsed it.

Because it's funny.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26217524
At 100k you start having issues with most forced induction engines. It's not a guarantee you will have problems but I wanted OP to be aware.

Turbos start getting to the end of their life around 100k for example. You could get 150k out of a turbo or the waste gate flap could become loose at 102k and suddenly you need a $2000 replacement turbo plus $600 labor. Diverter valves go around this milage too although that's usually a $200 fix at a shop. Pipes could age and cause boost leaks, etc.

I think the Lexus is a naturally aspirated V6 right? So you wouldn't have these issues

I think you guys hate on GM too much because you're "I'm smarter than everyone else" contrarian types. The other half of it is non-Americans coping for their fucked up domestic car market. Thanks to regulations from the government, owning a V8 engine is EXTREMELY expensive in most non-USA countries (like EU, Japan, etc.). So in those countries manufactures avoid them except for their top trim cars where the price is so high the owner can afford all of the heavy displacement taxes. The result is that people who love their EU or JDM cars have to find SOMETHING nice to say about their sports cars that get WORSE mileage and make LESS power yet weigh MORE than a GM V8 sports car. This is where the "soul" and "spirited" memes journos love to spout come from. Who can seriously make an argument for a 350z over a V8 sports car when they cost the same? You can't. But the thing is the 350z wasn't meant to win that fight, because it was meant for Japan where American V8 cars are not even allowed to be sold due to the engine size. The funniest part of all is that V8's like the Vette actually get BETTER gas mileage than inline four jap sports cars. GM has certainly had fuck ups, no denying it, but compare to competitors and you'll see the same shit. GM has owned and partnered with manufacturers on every continent for decades, they even build some of their cars in the same assembly lines as their competitors that you praise so highly. Just something to think about. There are also examples of utterly stellar engineering and reliability from GM that you all just ignore because it defeats all of your points. I say this as a person who drives a Japanese sports car. Your coping and seething is painful to watch, it's embarrassing, and you should stop.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'll make my case in defense of SLAV/Euro car and tuning culture.
With my decent understanding of American car culture and preferences to engines and mods, I can tell you a few reasons European car culture is so varied and different.
Under most countries' laws here, any car deal needs to be certified and registered to the individual, no pink slips or anything of the like.
Under EU law we are taxed on displacement and horsepower(KW) of the engine, which makes 1000cc-2500cc engines more than twice as cheap on YEARLY taxes as say a 4L V8.
Technical inspection is required once a year and power and emissions are tested to see if you're up to something funny maybe.
Tuning and mod culture. Varies a lot from country to country, with the more famous/notorious ones being UK and Slavic car scenes, with everything from riced out hatchbacks to tastefully tuned BMWs, Audis and Mercs.
The reasons why the Audi 1.9TDI and the 1.8t 20v engines are so popular is because they've been around in many different VAG cars and tunes over the years from 130hp to 240hp from the factory and can be pushed to 350hp on mostly OEM upgrades, which are cheap and abundant. Nothing beats swapping RS3 parts in your Polo.
Engine swaps are uncommon as you need to basically register the engine as a second car, we work with what we have and whatever has the most bang for the buck and can still remain road legal.
Our roads are also much different to the US, 250hp might not be much on the US highways, but it's plenty on twisting European B roads.

>It still sucks that the government taxes displacement so heavily
In the UK it's down to emissions what the tax is, not displacement. Depending on engines and trim for example, a 2015 Jaguar F-Type coupe can be as little as £330 a year to tax. That's a 3 litre supercharged AJV6 making around 340 horse. Somehow, the 2017 300 horse 4 pot turbo is £520 a year to tax. An R33 and R34 GTR is £295 a year. And tax rates are set in stone based on standard car emissions testing. It doesn't matter how much you modify it after, it'll always be whatever it's standard tune emissions are to tax. So long as it passes it's MOT (once yearly check), it's road legal.

It's £520 a year to tax a current generation Golf R. So if you shop around for used cars, you can find something that is infinitely more fun, cheaper to buy, cheaper to tax (but not nessecarily cheaper to insure depending on your age, or cheaper to run depending on what you buy).

If your car smells musty it's because there's mildew living in it somewhere. You need to find the source of it and actually clean it out and not try some bandaid gizmo "fix". First change your cabin air filter and make sure the evaporator box isn't filled with leaves and mold and crap.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26229342
>3.Tuning car engine is more difficult because more strict emissions requirements and testing.
Not really true. European emissions requirements only started catching up with American ones in the last ten years or so. Catalytic converters weren't even required until the 00's-- partly because Europeans were still running their cars on leaded gas into the 90's.

Regarding "testing", I assume you're talking about regular inspections. I'm from Texas, and I'm currently living in an EU country. While the rules might be more strict here on paper, they are far less strict in practice where I live. Both my cars have emissions systems deletes (catalyst and DPF in the diesel), which is considered pretty normal and commonplace here. It's not even hidden, but the cars pass inspection just fine. Actually, one of my cars just started throwing a code (I should probably hook it up to a reader at some point...) and displaying "Antipollution fault" on the information screen right before inspection was due. Local shop didn't give a shit. They rubber stamped the card, and I'm good for another two years.
>>26229707
>>Europe is one country
When it comes to laws, the EU is a more "one country" than the US is. For Americans who are unaware how this works, basically the executive branch of the EU (the European Commission, i.e. Ursala von der Leyen) writes the laws. Then the equivalent of the House and Senate (European Parliament and Council of Europe) get to vote on whether to pass the law. They get to keep voting until they agree that the law is a good idea. Once a law is passed by the EU, every country in the EU is then required to essentially transcribe the law into local law, and local government is expected to enforce those laws. So, for example, the EU has determined that the minimum sales tax in the EU should be 15%, and all EU countries are required to have laws setting sales tax at 15% or above. To American eyes this is really very strange.

That's because you're driving a based Accord, doesn't need to rev a lot to do work, but they do sound very unhappy at high rpms, the whole cylinder head is setup to run below 2400 rpm with half the intake valves shut off while cruising in 5th gear.

I've owned 2 ashtray cars.
the car will always have a smell of stale tobacco, mainly during hot days but, you can get most of it out.
I copied the typical "disaster detail" steps you see in yt vids complete with seat removal, center console removal, deep vacuuming, soap, borax, and oxiclean solutions used with an extractor and drill brush on every soft surface.
the only spot I didn't hit super hard was the headliner because it was already weak in some areas.
even after all that it leeches out some stink in the summer heat. charcoal or baking soda cabin filter helps a lot if you run recirculation

it might be worth it if it isn't that bad and you can tolerate the smell.

>>26226861

Well, I'm at a point where I'm kind of regretting getting a car. Perhaps it's the moment to buy some tools and learn or die trying. I have to change on this car:

>VVT solenoid (or its gasket). Will the solenoid break when I take it out?
>VVT spool valve filter
>Oil pressure switch assembly

All these 3 leak oil according to the mechanic that checked the car. Also have to change:

>Shocks
>Rear brake pads

How feasible it is to do this if I haven't even done oil changes?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26226906
I know it seems like the mechanic is trying to murder you with cost, but these are the things that do leak on Hondas, I even had VVT solenoid, the pressure switch, and the VTC strainer gasket leak myself. Since these cars are so reliable, I would check the oil every week or so depending on bad the car is leaking, and keep driving it to work, and fixing whatever you can afford to fix as you go about your business, whenever you get paid, buy some brake pads, whenever you get paid, buy a strut or two, and then keep saving and saving, until you can just show up at the shop and have everything done like I did, I would get a labor quote on everything, so that you know how much you need to save, a new Honda is breaking the bank, and then another used Honda is just gonna need the same things due to sheer age, so maybe fixing what you've got and continuing on as the rest of the car is healthy is a good idea.

OP go the electrolysis road. That's what professionals do too. (Simplyfied):

Another very interesting way of protecting your old tools could be the ancient method of bluing with linseed oil.
Basically you heat your old tools on a bbq grill and then quench them in raw(!) linseed oil, repeatedly if necessary.
The heat turns the oil into a pretty tough, glossy black / dark brown protective layer.

>but once again i find out these sprays are always a fucking toy scam
I mean, you can use them to cover stuff that doesn't make contact with anything. But that's a job for zinc-containing primers. For example I have used real zinc-primer on the chassis of an old lawn mower I've restored. There's also guys who use such primers when they're restoring car frames and stuff like that.
But when it comes to real toughness nothing beats a nice bubble bath in an electrolytic solution.
Oh I fortgot: Don't overdo it on your tools. If they're chinkonesium they might not be very true to size in general. But every zinc coat is a fraction of a millimeter thick. If you overdo it your wrenches might not fit the bolts anymore if you know what I mean. If you're afraid you might cover the inside of the blades (the parts that make contact with the bolts) with nail polish or something like that.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26230172
Multi-gear transmissions introduce more mechanical losses, and as already explained air resistance is the biggest drain for EVs.
Electric motors just don't burn more electricity at speed the way an internal combustion engine does.
So while you might gain some slight efficiency gain from the gear ratio, you'd also lose some from the mechanical losses.

The limiting factor for EVs when it comes to range isn't so much efficiency (unless you're going to Aptera levels of crazy out of the box design), its lack of stored energy. Even the longest range EV on the market today gets 500 miles out of less than the equivalent of 4 gallons of gas.
Also should add one of the things super efficient EVs do to eliminate more mechanical losses? Using hub motors that remove even more of the mechanical losses.

>Is that 42:17 including the charging stops?
Yes. That includes the charging stops with the time spent stationary. The average moving speed was as you might expect a lot faster. The way these teams are getting such fast cross-country times in an EV is they figure out exactly how much energy they need to dart between the fastest fast chargers at the top speeds the cars can handle.
Most of the decreases in the time are from deployment of better fast chargers, and cars with longer ranges and that can maintain max charging rates longer.

>The last time I checked they were doing around 30mph with recharging factored in.
Those were the kinds of times being achieved 9 years ago with 150kW fast chargers, and cars that really couldn't maintain that peak charging rate very long. Also didn't help that the first cross-country fast charger route took a very inefficient path

>Electric motors have efficiency bands just like ICE's.
While that's true, the extra mechanical losses make it kind of a wash. The main thing you need a multi-gear transmission for in an EV is a higher maximum speed, and considering how much energy that uses even with every advantage you can get, it just doesn't make sense until battery capacities equivalent to 6 gallon equivalents or more become available.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26230215
>I have literally no idea at all about what Tesla does, I can only assume they use a high voltage drivetrain and no gears
Their current cars except for the Plaid use a 400v architecture, and fixed gear ratios on their motors.
Plaid uses a 1000v architecture, and has a new motor design that can vary the mechanical advantage using different winding ratios.

Porsche by contrast uses an 800v architecture in the Taycan, and has a 2 speed multi-gear transmission for the rear motor.
But for the Taycan that extra gear ratio is about better launch performance and a higher top speed than it is efficiency.

The big advantage for going higher voltage for an EV is decreased performance fade as the battery drains, and being able to support faster charging.

So first off that would be just 150 Wh/kg which is pretty low by modern standards. Model 3 used cheaper batteries 5 years ago and did 170 Wh/kg pack density. I think the best batteries demoed in real working vehicles are around 210 Wh/kg pack density. Which would make that pack around 4 gallon equivalent.

Also keep in mind that the battery is the biggest weight in an EV. With a 100kWh battery pack an Aptera Paradigm is still only going to weigh about 1000kg.
Being roughly twice as efficient as a Tesla, ~100 Wh/km at speed means being able to go twice as far on the same energy.
Which is a big deal since lack of stored energy is the biggest issue for BEVs.

Of course, the Aptera's super simple powertrain design and the relatively more open policies to repair and modification could open up being able to carry way more stored energy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26230071
Okay, so let's go over this like you're a little kid since that's the mental capabilities you're working with. As the pads wear down, the sensor also gets ground away. This means that the friction from the rotor is removing material from the sensor. Eventually it removes enough of this material that it reaches an embedded wire. The wire has a signal going through it so the cars computer knows it is still intact. Once it reaches the wire, it actually breaks it into two pieces. Now that the wire is broken and the sensor is ground down, the computer doesn't seem the signal and knows the brakes need to be changed. And you're asking why the sensor that got ground against the rotor until it broke the internal wire can't just be reused?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26226080
Electric AWD is easy to achieve, just put an electric motor/generator on the front axle, which is also optimal for use with KERS. For a PHEV like this, that motor generator should let them eliminate a lot of complexity from the gas range extender engine as well since it will no longer need a traditional alternator, and they'll almost certainly have electric climate control as well, like using a heatpump to move heat from the powertrain to the cabin.

AWD with a MR layout pure ICE car requires you to have a driveshaft going from the transmission at the rear forward to the front axle. Its a lot harder to engineer and you don't get any advantages from doing it that way.
You may not like it from a philosophical purity perspective, but PHEV really is the best solution today.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26229840
Your tyre is the "suspension" for your cars suspension components. Driving without one removes all the shock absorption that protects those components.

In your case, you drove a mile. Not terrible, not great. You definitely need a tyre. You will need to have the inside of the wheel checked for buckling on a wheel balancer, that's 50/50 on wether or not it'll be damaged, depends on the wheel/road conditions you drove over.
Other than that, expect that damper/shock absorber to last half as long as the one on the other side.
They'll also need to check the wheel studs to ensure that rimming your car like a Basketball American didn't fatigue them.

Probably no reason to panic, but next time swap it for the spare.
You fucking ape.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26229840
Use insurance to get a tow to wherever you buy tires from. If you bought that set of tires currently on the vehicle and you have some sort of road hazard warranty, you're in luck. Take it to wherever you bought the tires from, get the claim taken care of, and enjoy your new tire. If not, a tire + installation at a dealership or tire shop chain will probably probably run you around $200 depending on what tire you buy.
Chances are you may have bent the wheel when you hit the pothole, more often than not a bent wheel is safe to repair. Find a local wheel repair business, most are mobile and will come to your car, leave it on a jackstand or spare wheel, and you'll have your wheel back in a day or so. May run you $75-$125 depending on who you hire. If you're really unlucky and the wheel is so bent that it won't hold air or that the wheel is cracked, get a new one. You can probably find a used one on Facebook Marketplace for around $100, just search "Ford Fusion wheel" and be sure that it's the same design with the same size tire. Or, you can order a brand new one from your local for dealer for I'm guessing $800

>>26230150
>What is unsprung weight.
No such thing as a stupid question, anon. Pretty much everything under the strut spring seat does not have road surface undulations absorbed by the suspension system.
These need to be strong enough to deal with that while not being too heavy to have their movement properly regulated by the dampers.
The tyre acts as their buffer zone between them and the road just as the suspension does between your car and the wheels on said road.

>>26227611
All of those gauges are a waste and are more likely to just freak you out if they fail. You just need lights showing oil/coolant is cold still and everything else just needs a light if it's out of normal spec. I can't tell you how many people freak out when Summer hits and they forget that cars run hotter in the Summer and are wondering if they should change 600 parts on their car when it's just doing normal shit. Oil pressure is the least valuable, on any car I've ever seen it's either normal or your engine is blown and it's too late. On most cars, the gauge fails before the actual oil pressure varies from normal, so you just get a false panic. All of this shit, if included at all, should only be accessible deep in a diagnostic menu for troubleshooting but never shown during normal use.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
They're unapologetic shitboxes and do their job with varying degrees of success.
Sure you can't compare a Zhiguli to an E30 BMW, but when compared to something closer to their price point like an opel kadett or vauxhall viva (same car basically) they're not THAT bad.
People tend to forget how shitty European cars were in general around the 70s..

They also tend to be extremely cheap when compared to contemporary western cars due to not being that desirable.
I bought my Skoda 120GLS for 180 bucks, most of the parts were there but it was stripped almost completely and the engine was a goner, an Opel Kadett C would've been at least 800 bucks in similar condition, a KE70 Corolla would run me at least a grand in similar albeit much rustier condition because toyota.
So when you want a VERY cheap RWD winter drifter, ice ring racer or a project car, you can get old soviet cars for a fraction of the price of a western car.

>>26215669
What's cool about it is that it visits a past which was never allowed to be. Soviet cars in period weren't modified heavily, there just wasn't a car culture like there was in the USA. So cars were just left to be tools instead of a signifier.
And modifying combloc cars goes back on that, and asks questions like "what if I slammed a Niva on bags and repainted it?" or "Why not drop a v12 into a GAZ and chrome plate the grill and other trim?"
And so on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26217599
Not only that but most of the times modifying cars in the union was varying degrees of illegal, they had quite strict inspections, you had to write down and catalogue all the modifications you did and you could only use permitted parts.
My old man had a Moskvich 408 with the opel derived 1.3 litre pushrod engine, the timing gear was glued onto a bakelite wheel that tended to crack and slip, smashing the valves into the pistons.
Old man replaced the valves twice, spun a bearing scoring the crank while doing 130kmh downhill, got a second engine from a junkyard and filed down the serial numbers and punched in his previous serial, cracked the crank on that engine and got fed up with the bullshit, replacing the whole drivetrain with an imported BMW M10B18 and a 4 speed manual from a BMW 1802 wreck that was smuggled from west germany and sold on the black market.
Helped him a lot as he was an air force pilot to pass police checkups and such

Whoever this is is moron talking out of his ass and doesn't understand that technical regulations don't stay static for decades. Rules change and cars can be eligible for different categories. The McLaren F1 didn't race under the same GT1 regs in 1997 as it did in the years prior. The Toyota GT-One was recategorized as a GTP when GT1 was cancelled. The Viper GTS/R raced as a GT1 in its first year, then rehomologated as a GT2. It'd also race under the IMSA/ACO rules in the GTS category. Then you had the Maserti MC-12 which didn't conform to re-vamped GT1 regs of mid-'00s, but was granted homologation on a waiver anyway because Mosley demanded it.

The main takeaway is that rules change and different racing series can categorize cars as they see fit. GT1 in 1994 was not the same as GT1 in 2005 or GTS in 2001 or GT in 2003. They are all different rule sets.

>>26194439
>>26194907
The desolation in sportscar racing caused by the subsequent collapse of Gr.C (and Gr.B a few years before) led to fans looking at more national-level and single-make series to get their fix. Under these circumstances, Venturi made their own one-make series in 1992 called the Gentleman Driver's Trophy for amateurs which garnered a lot of attention despite being side-events for bigger races. The series used their 400 Trophy racecar and got a lot of response from teams. In charge of the series was Venturi's head of competition services, Stephane Ratel, who is practically the godfather of the modern GT era. In 1993, facing a dwindling prototype field, the ACO allowed production-based cars to fill the rest of the grid for the first time since 1986. The response to their Trophy series and a chance for competing at the LM24, Venturi stepped up to the plate with the 500LM and were represented by no less than 7 cars. They didn't win, but most of the cars actually succeeded in finishing the race.

In 1994, Ratel teamed up with Jurgen Barth and Patrick Peter to make the BPR series which would aim to become the first intercontinental sportscar series since Gr.C folded. Ratel would apply his connections from the Trophy series to get teams to race in BPR giving Venturi a strong presence in a field that would otherwise be a slew of 911s and a single F40 for most of the races. The BPR would continue to grow in 1995 and 1996 with Venturi competing every year until it was taken over by the FIA. During the BPR years Ratel would form the SRO which has been shaping GT racing for almost 30 years.

First, nice Double-Dubs.

Second, something to add was that the performance spike and extremely high running costs of Group C & GTP cars in America in the early 1990s lead to many privateer teams and gentlemen drivers to look elsewhere, which in turn lead to a rise in One-Make series like the Porsche Super Cup and the Ferrari Challenge series. The head if Porsche's competition department at the time? Jurgen Barth.

The biggest mover and shaker in the Ferrari Challenge series when it launched in the 1990s? Patrick Peter.

By early 1993, Stephane Ratel, Barth and Peter started organizing special race weekends where teams in their one-make series that were up for it raced against each other. By Le Mans that year, the BPR GT series was starting to take shape and they just so happened to use the rulebook Le Mans came up with for 1994.

I think Peter's clout back in the '90s was promoting events, especially vintage motorsport. Before BPR, his organization brought back the modern interpretation of the French Tour Auto event in 1992. He would later go on to start the Le Mans Classic in the early-'00s. His connection was useful in filling up the grid as many teams were just amateur drivers that owned or maintained classic racecars.

Barth was basically just famous for his career as a Porsche factory driver having 4 class wins at LM24 with one of those being an outright win in a 936. He was just there to put a famous face on the series and his final class win happened just months before the first BPR race. Essentially the spokesman, he held a lot of celebrity sway over Porsche enthusiasts (and probably why so many teams on the grid were driving Porsches)

Ratel was the main guy running the whole operation. He also used his connections at Venturi to get teams from the Trophy series to sign on to BPR and step up the Trophy cars to one of the new 500LM racecars.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Jesus Christ, too many normies in this thread flinging shit at each other without actually knowing whose shit it is.

The GTS/R originally raced as a GT1 car when it debuted in 1996. Back then the main deciding factor of which category a car belonged was based on engine displacement. The Viper being 8.0L was firmly designated for GT1. When the FIA revised their rules for 1997 (mainly to allow for more exotic cars and technology like the CLK GTR), Chrysler had the GTS/R rehomologated for FIA's GT2. For the US races, they would race under the SCCA's GT2 category for USRRC races and IMSA/ACO's GTS category for ALMS. When USRRC gave way to Grand-Am, the GTS/R was in the GTO category until they renamed it GTS (many of the same cars as ACO, but under GARRA's rules) until Vipers were no longer running in the series. These different categories in different series were basically analogous to FIA's pre-'97 regs.

When ACO adopted the FIA's newly revised GT regs essentially adapting the old GTS and GT classes as new GT1 and GT2, the GTS/R was categorized as a GT1 under the new rules. By adopting the ACO's GTS rules, in a round-about way, the FIA returned to GT1 back to what it was before the 1997 changes.

That's the 1999 D24. That event was part of the USRRC in those days which ran under the SCCA rules. Under those rules, the C5-R (and the EMR Corvette) was categorized as a GT2 which was a ported version of FIA GT1 for the US. So the "GT2" decal on the car does denote the category car is racing in because it's an SCCA GT2 which is different from FIA GT2.

>>26190497
The story of the 911 GT1 is a silly one. The only reason why Porsche got into GT1 in the first place was because their 1995 prototype project fell through and ACO banned them from racing a 962 in a GT category after '94. Instead of complying with the rules of not entering a prototype in a GT class, they would build a new prototype and have the rules changed later and so they came out with the 911 GT1 for '96. They'd win some races in BPR, but because it wasn't homologated at the time, it didn't count for any championship points. When the FIA took over BPR and updated the rules, irony Porsche as it was getting beaten at their own game by the new Mercedes and updated McLaren. For most of the program, the car was getting its butt-kicked in FIA GT and could only muster a few non-championship exhibition races. Their only consolation prize was a championship in the national-level BGTC.

It was in 1998 that they went go-for-broke in the final year of the program and completely revised the car. They still got their ass handed to them in FIA GT (and lost their BGTC crown to a McLaren team), but they did end up winning Le Mans. However to do it, Porsche had to buyout the LMP team that had been beating them over the last two years and "upgrade" their cars. Both would DNF leaving the GT1 cars the sole factory-supported team. The biggest irony was that the LMP car that kept beating them before was the using Porsche's abandoned prototype project from before.

The final black eye of the program was at the final race of the factory program at the very first Petite Le Mans where they DNF'd by managing to get the car airborne and flip over end-over-end.

A stupid end to a stupid car.

>>26221420
>I’d argue the absurd performance gap the McLaren F1 had when it started racing against other road cars is what led to the batshit stuff like the GT-One and CLK-lm
Nope. The F1 GTR was perfectly compliant with the GT1 regs at the time. The performance gap was because McLaren was the only manufacturer focusing on GT1 at the time and the car just being a better car than everybody else.

The 911 GT1 was not eligible for homologation under the then-current rules when it debuted in 1996 hence why it did not score any championship points. Porsche had to wait for the new rules the following year for the car to be properly homologated. It was that rule change, initiated by Porsche, that led to the prototype GT1 cars.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've been looking at part numbers, spec sheets and compatibility charts again.
Turns out the brake setup on the Espace 1/2 is very similar to the Clio Williams, which is identical to the one found on late 16V Twingos (same caliper mounting hole spacing, same brake disc diameter, they even take the same brake pads), but with one crucial difference: the Espace calipers get much bigger pistons (54mm vs 48mm).
They also cost less than 50 eurobucks a pop brand new. Might need a new master cylinder to compensate for the increased pedal travel but this is all very promising, it's not quite a big brake kit but it should all still just barely fit under 14" wheels and get you some extra stopping power.

Also if you upgrade to 15x6-7" wheels you can run Goodyear Eagle F1s in 195/45R15, which sounds hilarious for trackday sessions.

posts.com:
>>26226818
Oh and forgot to mention, if they work on the mk1 they should also work all the way up to the mk2 GT, the RS gets bigger discs and different 57mm calipers, from the Laguna I believe.

>>26227662
What context do you need? Proving my point by the real truck engine being an L6?
Owning is not the same as understanding. Fundamentally, a diesel is not limited by displacement. It does not need a set compression ratio like a gasoline engine, so the best configuration is the whatever has the strongest bottom end.
The reason V shaped engines are used for gasoline is that their physical size allows more displacement than an L6 counterpart. So, their bottom end is 'strong enough' for an 11:1 compression ratio. It's a good compromise. For a gasoline engine.
Making a V-shaped diesel is fundamentally retarded. Wait till you have to do something simple like a valve cover gasket or intake gasket with your turbo sitting in the fucking valley of the engine.
Like I said, no thanks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I mean you definitely could but they're not good cars from the factory, why would you want one?

Open diffs so it understeers everywhere, small brakes, weak transmission and block that goes at 320~ whp (either it'll spin a rod bearing or break a gear), and stock they dyno at 190-200whp so it's not fast in a 3200lb car with 3.9 final drive (JDM cars had 4.44 FDs so they felt quicker from shorter gearing). Tiny TD04 doesn't spool until 3500 and you have to shift around 5500-6000rpms because it runs out of breath. The wagons all got taken off the road in the salt states due to really bad corrosion at the rear strut towers and they all have bad oil/power steering leaks (fuel leaks too)

Honestly WRXs are just compromise cars meant for people who have to have one single car, do yourself a favor sell that Corvette for $15k, buy a VB WRX for $30k and at least it'll hold 400whp with a intake/exhaust/tmic/tune. Or look for a JDM Imported 1998 v5 STi for $15-20k. Or look for a 02-05 WRX with a EJ207 swap for $10k~ if you can find one that isn't a rusty shitbox.

Determination really is the key.
When I was a kid I went a few times and it took 2 hours to get down the mountain because I crashed so much.
But I knew it was something I wanted to do and would enjoy if I just had the opportunity to practice.
Once I moved and was 45 minutes from the resort I just went by myself as often as I could.
My first board/bindings was from a local who bought a new setup. It was the price of 2 days rental, well worth it. (I still have that board).
I've bought boards off fleabay in the off season (I've paid more for shipping than the board). I scored a basically brand new Jeenyus (pre Burton buyout) for my girlfriend that looked like some chick got her dad to buy her gear, tried the bunny slope once and said fuck it. So it's definitely worth it to shop around and wait for a deal.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26200766
>the jeep compass trailhawk pro -
For the love of God do NOT buy one. I owned one for two years after having a cheap ass jeep patriot i got at 17 that lasted 11 years. The patriot was ok and it could offroad just enough. BUT the compass "trailhawk" was the biggest peice of shit. The brand new engine burned a quart of oil every 1000 miles, which I only found out because one day driving down the highway my engine shuts off at 60 mph after a "low oil pressure" warning flashed up for 5 seconds. This happened the first time aound 10k miles. And several times after that despite me pouring a fresh quart in once a month. I was then told that the oil consumption rate was normal by the dealership. Aside from that I had shit break on it constantly. Half the parts are from a fiat 500 and it's 4wd is actually just AWD. The final nail in the coffin was when my battery died, but it wasn't actually my battery. It was a very small sub battery that sat on top of my normal battery that INDEPENDENTLY powered the starter motor. So I had a totally fine battery, but because some AA Duracell shit was dead the fucking car wouldn't start. I sold it back to the dealership and bought a 4runner instead and it runs like a dream.

Wrong. There are breathable and rainproof motorcycle clothes available, but these clothes are more often made from textile materials than leather. To reduce fogging issues to visor of the helmet there are Pinlock visor's available that can be installed to helmet or mounted to stock visor. Also there are breath deflectors available that can be installed into helmet and these breath deflectors reduce fogging by preventing the rider from breathing out directly to visor.

Dont drive much above speedlimit and should be quite safe even on rainy days. Tires should be good quality and correct type for the motorcycle because lots of tires that can be mounted to the rims but they dont offer proper traction with a wrong type motorcycle. Tires should be less than 6 years old and not bald.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26220881
Aeronautical engineer with 15 years experience designing, testing and analyzing large-scale composite structures.

Forged composites cannot exist in definition. Forging implies pressing the material with such extreme pressure and heat that it reshapes (metallic) grain structure (usually, "hot working" a metal). You cannot do this with composites. In fact, quite the opposite; it will break the strand and make the woven fabric and/or strands weaker.

Also, the vast majority of composites are cured under pressure to create compaction (namely for strength, but occasionally and especially for aesthetics). This is why complex shapes still contain the "woven" aesthetic; it's not only for looks, but for strength. Anything that is mold form that didn't show the weave (Ie, OP's pic) would immediately be rejected in the aviation world, and is absolutely absurd the word "forged" is implied. I am disgusted by it.

We typically refer to this material as "random orient" (due to the lack of fiber direction), "chopped fiber," or "recycled." It is never used that I have seen. We sell it off (rare) or just send it to the landfill.

>tl;dr
You can't "forge" composites, it's a marketing ploy

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26223631
Lamborghini supposedly uses the same process as Boeing does for various parts of the 787, which basically involves loading a bunch of pre-preg chopped fibers into a mold and then heating it up and applying a lot of pressure. I'm guessing the heat is just to speed up the resin curing as apparently you have a functional part after just 3 minutes of heat and pressure.
They say the "forged" part of the name comes from "the goal of replacing metal forgings in cars", which sounds like a lot of marketing talk, but it is a process used in the aviation industry.

>>26220881
maker here.
it is obviously not forged but lambo coined that term and now everyone uses it so it's on them.
it is a valid way of making parts, easier and cheaper than regular carbon, and it fills a volume instead of forming a skin so comparative loss in strength is compensated by thickness. if you need strong lightweight parts at any cost then proper laid-up carbon or metals are unbeatable, but if you just need strength and stiffness (and possibly heat resistance) in a small part then forged works, it's multiple steps up from any 3d printed parts in terms of material properties while not requiring much in terms of extra skills or hardware- print a mold, fill with tow and epoxy, press, smelly and messy but anyone can do it, not much different from diy poly bushings.

>>26226174
OSB is made from larger wood chips and typically impregnated with resins to repel moisture. It’s most commonly used as a substitute for plywood in construction. Particle board Is made from finer particles than OSB, so it shittier. MDF is made from even finer particles, sawdust mixed with binder, so it’s the weakest of the three. They all have a use depending on the application.

>>26227227
first of all, based
I too drive an unregistered uninsured old jap 4x4 with emissions problems

never have to worry about a parking ticket lol

here is the thing though -
cats usually don't fail by themselves, if you replace them without addressing the possible causes you will just fry the new cats in a few months. with a 281,000 mile vehicle it is conceivable that it burns oil either through piston ring wear or leaks through valve stem seals or spark plug tube seals etc, thereby fouling the cat. It is extremely unprofessional for Toyota to offer you a bandaid repair without addressing the root causes

another aspect of this is that as others have said, the cats could be fine and the fucked O2 sensor(s) are giving erroneous readings. It could be the motor is relatively healthy but the cat(s) failed due to a lifetime of mild oil consumption. erroneous O2 readings can even lead to incorrect fuel trims leading to cat failure.

Overall, it is a complex issue which requires thorough investigation to repair appropriately.

My recommendations would be - register in SD, Vermont, or a non-emissions county in AZ. I probably wouldn't falsify a document if they share the info with police.

I would think long and hard about the value of completing repairs to that vehicle but I don't know its true condition

posts.name: Lm7bird
posts.com:
Just got back from test driving the sway bars I put in. 1-2am nobody was on the road so I was able to Hoon that poor car for everything it's got. And man does it have more to give. First I'm gonna say one of the biggest improvements aside from the obvious was launch stability. The rear end stayed flat and it felt like both tires had even grip even under a hard launch which is impressive considering the whole open diff thing and the rear sway bar probably does something to help with axle wrap. Now for the obvious, around the corners it stayed perfectly flat with almost no understeer and the throttle input to induce oversteer was far more predictable and importantly consistent allowing me to kick out the rear end counter steer and get the car going the right way. The abundance of right hand turns made this easy to test and get a hang of. My only complaint is the car seems to rock now which kinda sucks going from my glorified boat suspension but the performance gain and the tire wear aspect of not leaning onto the outside shoulders of the tires should make the bullshit all completely worth it.
>Mfw I hit this right turn at 40 with the most graceful power slide before flooring it away and hitting redline

>>26220351
If the drum gives a bit and then goes back like there's a spring then there's a lip on the inside of the drum that's catching the brake shoes so you would need to back the adjuster screw off to collapse the rear brake shoes to the point you can get the lip on the drum over them.

If the thing is solid with zero give then it's rusted onto the axle hub, and more specifically to the centering hub. A BFH and pry bar will be needed. Pry the drum out such as you can while beating the fuck out of the center hub. This is literally a pain due to the studs, but needs must.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26222078
I own a 2006 with almost 80K miles now. It's an absolute joy to drive, especially with a few suspension and power mods.

Maintenance isn't horribly expensive but do expect it to cost more than your average Japanese econobox. They're quite easy to work on yourself, the only catch is things may be in the way so a lot of the labor time is spent getting access to the thing you're trying to fix.

Driving feel is excellent, especially if you have PASM or coilovers on the car. It's more than comfortable enough to drive it as a daily (I sometimes do for a week here and there). I've tracked it a couple times and it wasn't as fun as my Lotus Elise but it's an unfair comparison since the Lotus is pretty much built with the track in mind. I drove my Cayman on a 2000 mile road trip over 5 days and was perfectly comfortable. I'd recommend finding one with the optional sport seats though.

Things to watch out for when buying are bore score and AOS failure. Everyone talks about IMS but if the car already has some miles on it and IMS hasn't failed, I wouldn't worry about it. Just have it replaced when you get a clutch job done.
